qas.question: How long did the armistice talks last?
What issues stalled the armistice talks?
What was deemed unacceptable to North Koreans and the Chinese during POW negotiations?

answers.text: many PVA and KPA soldiers refused to be repatriated back to the north

qas.question: When was the armistice agreement finally signed?
What was established to deal with the issues surrounding prisoners of war?

context: The on-again, off-again armistice negotiations continued for <a0_0>two years<a0_0/>, first at Kaesong, on the border between North and South Korea, and then at the neighbouring village of Panmunjom. A major, problematic negotiation point was <a1_0>prisoner of war (POW) repatriation<a1_0/>. The PVA, KPA, and UN Command could not agree on a system of repatriation because <a2_0>many PVA and KPA soldiers refused to be repatriated back to the north<a2_0/>, which was unacceptable to the Chinese and North Koreans. In the final armistice agreement, signed on <a3_0>27 July 1953<a3_0/>, a <a4_0>Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission,<a4_0/> under the chairman Indian General K. S. Thimayya, was set up to handle the matter.
